A word of caution to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it exactly the same questions as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences whereas others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1944, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaire

Saskatchewan Archives Questions which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Presentation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be presented in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archivist at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Village of Pleaton, Manitoba - 1902.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.). I was taken there by my parents - I was then 2 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West? My father's wish.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people's reading about it? Reading or government information?).

My father learned of it by Canadian Government information when living in Scotland - learned of free homesteads.
12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use? My older brother and sister used an old car and 9 year old motorcycle and myself transported from Prince Albert.

14. What happened after you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Only remember being afraid driving north on the old Touchwood Trail with my family from Lillooet when border became strict of a real wood trail with an old hanging rope tree rear axle of the wagon in which we all were riding. The oxen (named "Pick and Pans") pulled the wagon very slowly through our first prairie fire.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At Lillooet, and then after ox wagon trip to nearest settler's house to have supper.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? On S.W. 1/4, S.W. 1/4, R.14, East and West.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

British Columbia, Ontario, England (short periods).

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Child before coming, farmed, and then enlisted at age of 20 years in Royal Canadian Mounted Police - served 25 years and took pension for life - presently as Detective-Staff Sergeant - now doing investigation work.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Child before coming - Farming, and then I started at about 20 years old in Royal Canadian Mounted Police - served 20 years until I took pension. After that I was doing investigation work.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

The most outstanding in my memory is the first but get the beauty of a distant prairie fire burning at night — fear of being burned by its little flames, and the beauty of watching little fires in the evening darkness on hill slopes, valleys and bluffs against a pitch black night.

As I grew older we were expected to light them when we came our house and property, in one occasion due to a spark from an iron ore burning and settle around a crop after harvesting, and a generous German.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often did you visit? By what means of transport?

No. Church was held by way of services in the early settlements mostly by travelling ministers. Any visiting was either done by wagon drawn by oxen and later by horseless automobiles by automobile. Later by car, motorcycle and bus, sometimes horseback — with or without saddle.
